newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong workers' pay increases seen shrinking.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong workers' pay increases seen shrinking.

text.p: Hong Kong workers received an average 2.5 percent in real pay rises in 1996, down from 1995, and salary increases will be even smaller in 1997, results from a management institute survey released on Tuesday showed.
"The results of the 1996 Pay Trend Survey showed a weighted average increase of 8.5 percent," said Patrick Maule, chairman of the Hong Kong Institute of Human Resource Management's Survey Committee.
"This means that 1996 provided real increases of about 2.5 percent given an average inflation of six percent for the year," he said.
The total pay increases were 1.6 percent less than in 1995.
About 80 percent of the 113 Hong Kong companies in the survey, which have their next salary review in January, predicted an even lower increase in 1997.
Salary increases had been falling since 1989, as had inflation, Maule said.
Staff turnover fell to 18.4 percent in the 12 months to June 1996, down from 24.1 percent in the previous year, the survey showed.

"The general economic downturn has resulted in an appreciable drop in staff turnover in all business sectors, but there is still plenty of room for improvement," said survey co-chairwoman Gloria Chan.
